thread.title: Pheasants to be released for hunters
thread.title_full: Pheasants to be released for hunters

title: Pheasants to be released for hunters
text:
Pheasants to be released for hunters Dick Martin, Correspondent 7:35 p.m. EDT October 13, 2015 Buy Photo Sean Murphy, a wildlife technician with the Ohio Department of Natural Resources’ Division of Wildlife, releases pheasant at Dillon Wildlife Area in Nashport. The state plans on releasing 17,000 pheasant for the hunting season. (Photo: Chris Crook/Times Recorder ) Buy Photo CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
More than 15,000 ring-necked pheasants will be released at 25 public hunting areas this fall to provide additional hunting opportunities for outdoorsmen. The Division of Wildlife will be releasing pheasants on Oct. 23 and 30, prior to the small-game season weekends for youth hunters. Youngsters age 17 and younger can hunt statewide for rabbit, pheasant, and all other legal game in season during two designated weekends, Oct. 24-25 and Oct. 31-Nov. 1. Ohio’s small game hunting season begins on Friday, Nov. 6, with pheasant releases to take place Nov. 5, and 13. A final release of the year is scheduled to provide pheasant hunting opportunities throughout the Thanksgiving holiday weekend and will take place on Nov. 25. Among the wildlife areas that will receive birds are Delaware, Killdeer Plains, Resthaven, Shreve, Spencer, Salt Fork and Grand River. For a full list of the 25 public hunting areas, visit bit.ly/pheasantlocations. 
Acorns are down in wildlife areas 
There’s good news and bad news for hunters this fall. The 2015 Ohio acorn mast survey conducted at 38 wildlife areas showed a decrease in production from 2014. That’s bad news since the acorn crop, particularly white oaks, are an important food source for wild creatures from deer and wild turkeys to squirrels, so important for deer particularly, that they’ll often abandon farm crops and other foods like alfalfa to feast on the protein, fat and carbohydrate rich nuts. Overall there was a 23 percent decrease for white oaks in the number of trees bearing acorns. The good news? The poor mast crop should improve deer hunter success, particularly among archers, because deer will be moving more to actively search for food. 
Waterways safety council looking for members 
Those interested in boating issues might like to visit the Waterways Safety Council’s quarterly meeting at 10 a.m. Oct. 28. The Council is a five-member citizen advisory council which provides input on boating issues to the Division of Watercraft. The meeting will be held at the Ohio Department of Natural Resources, Division of Watercraft, 2045 Morse Road, Bldg C, Columbus, OH 43229. People interested in attending the council meeting should contact Jane Turner at 614-265-6476. 
Youth and mobility impaired hunter lottery to be held 
Lottery drawings will be held for youth and mobility impaired hunters wishing to participate in deer hunts at Maumee Bay State Park. Twenty lottery applications will be selected for each hunt. There will be a mobility-impaired hunt on Nov. 7 and 8 with the drawing Oct. 22. Applications must be postmarked by Oct. 19 and selected hunters will be contacted. The youth hunts will be on Nov. 14 and Nov. 15 with a drawing on Oct. 29. Applications must be postmarked by Oct. 26. Youth hunters must be under the age of 18 on the day of the hunt. Applicants must possess a current Ohio hunting license and deer tag. Applicants under 18 must have a parent or legal guardian present to sign the permit contract. For applications, visit maumeevalleynwff.com. 
Dick Martin is retired biology teacher who has been writing outdoor columns for 30 years. You can each him at richmart@neo.rr.com . Read or Share this story: http://ohne.ws/1Lt6fFh TOP VIDEOS
